Some fidget spinner addons I slapped together over the weekend, partly because I don't know when I'll get to a bearing shop.

  1. bearing_nut_adaptor - adapt a m8, m10 or 3/8" nut to fit in your favourite fidget spinner (replacing the bearings used as weights
  2. pla_bearing - a pla fitting that fits inside the centre hole of your favourite fidget spinner as surprisingly good bearing replacement (i.e. works comparable to normal bearings, but doesn't come close to low resistance bearings)
  3. bearing_press - tools that make it easier to press in bearings into your favourite fidget spinner.

description.text:
This is an articulated Magikarp. It can move its spine and fins. It is a high poly model and can be scaled up to be very big and not lose a lot of quality.

Parts are pre-orientated for a single material printer to give best detail and strength but may need tweaking depending on your printer and settings.
Glue will most likely be needed, but may not at a larger size.

If you have a multi material printer. I have uploaded STL files that I believe are optimized for it though a lot of it will be guesswork as I have only got a single material printer and cant test it myself.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2322274

I have also posted this on MyMiniFactory containing the blender files for those who want them.
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/35692

Hope you like it.

Credits.
Modeled by me buy uses a modified version the the ball joint by ELLINDSEY
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:584405

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

Needed on some parts.

Notes:

All of the Red body parts can be printed at your chosen scale. Then print the rest 1% - 3% less depending on how accurate/tolerant your printer is, The larger your model the less you need to shrink the other parts.

Support is needed on most parts, mainly to help them stick to the bed, but the orientation is done to minimize the damage to the bottom and where parts are hidden. (May need to tweak it slightly depending on your slicer settings.)

Infill is needed on some parts. But it does not need a lot, just enough to give the concave parts, mouth and top fin and tail fin something to start printing on.

I printed mine with the red parts at 150% everything else as 147%. I would not recommend going smaller than this because some of the parts are rather delicate.
Layer height was 0.1mm as that is the best my printer can do.
Infill was I think around 10%

Cr10 Printer if you're curious.

description.text:
With this model, you can upcycle the glass jars commonly found in Europe into mini greenhouses for your plants. It has a water reservoir and a lip to collect condensation water and re-inject it in the reservoir (See cross-section image for detail). With the hexagonal design, you can pack them in a honeycomb pattern or mix sizes easily.

I have created 4 models matching 4 different sizes but you can easily design new sizes for your jar.

To find your size, measure the outer diameter of the opening of the jar.

The 72mm is also available with larger sides because my apple purée jars have narrow opening but are quite wide, this is to allow to pack them together without the glass touching.

Watering tips:
If you keep the glass jar on it, don't use the reservoir or keep the water level in it very low (0,5 cm), because the greenhouse will be closed, the water that you put will not evaporate and the soil will be too wet. Use the reservoir only when not using the glass.

Happy Farming!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

As the design is quite simple, you should be able to print at fast speed. Printing at 60 or 80mm/s should not be a problem on a Prusa i3 MK2.

If your printer allows it and to add some color, I suggest that you do a color change at layer 251 (Z 50.2mm).

If you are using Simplify 3D, you can rotate your model on the z-axis by 45° to align top solid infill with the side for a nicer look.

Wall thickness is designed to print 2 perimeters at 0.45 mm layer width.

Edit it to fit your jar!

I designed this in Fusion 360 and it can be easily modified to fit more glass jars.
You can download my designs from Autodesks' A360.
52.5mm file: http://a360.co/2pPES0l
62mm file: http://a360.co/2ql1CZx
72mm file: http://a360.co/2r9Lvzh
78mm file: http://a360.co/2qlas9V

In the pictures above, you can find an explanation of how the measurements are taken.
2017-05-17: Renamed file for 52.5mm (was wrongly named 57mm)

comments.text: If you are printing at 0.1 layer height, you should set more than 3 layers for top and bottom else your printer parts will have only 0.3 mm shells which is pretty weak compared to probably 3 perimeters at 0.45 mm so about 1.2mm thickness.  At 0.1 mm layer height you should go at least 6 layers for top and bottom. Extrusion seems to be good yes. Any particular reason why you have a brim? The model is flat and should do well without brim but this is not the reason why it is leaking. Also this is an utilitarian object so usually for this kind of objects I print at 0.15 or 0.2 at a pretty high speed, but it depends on your printer capabilities, I think it takes less than 4 hours to print for me. 110 degrees in the other user comment was in Farenheit as 110C will make your object flat if printer with PLA ;-)

comments.text:
That is weird, do you usually get a first layer like this on your prints? Usually the first layer should be squished enough so it is flat. Maybe you need to redo your first layer/bed calibration. Which slicer are you using?
Even if the first layer is not perfect, there are many layers above and it should fill the gaps.
You can also try to rotate your part or the infill angle so it is aligned with the walls. See attached image of one that I have printed in 2h34 last year, the bottom infill is parallel to one of the walls.
comments.author: Fitze

comments.text: I am using Slic3r to generate the Gcode. I could try to calibrate again, I have had issues going too close to the bed, it seemed like the extruder was pushing the PLA into the bed, which made it almost impossible to get the parts of the blue tape.
comments.author: Milhooz

comments.text: Usually it is best to disable the fan for the first layer (I disable it for the first 3 layers) but it depends on the print surface, I have PEI surface on my Prusa MK2S. I have no experience of other surfaces so I could not say. Speed depends on the printer capabilities and on the Slicer as well.

comments.text:
Nice idea - but i see a minor problem ... more a missing piece.
If the plant has grown a proper root ball, it can not be removed from your pot without damaging or destroying the pot or the root ball.
In order to be able to easily repot the plant, a insert is needed.
http://pichoster.adbt2.ath.cx/viewpic/planter-upgradejpgDa8VIDk.jpg
The green line represents the insert. As with hydroculture, the water is supplied to the plant with some sort of thick yarn, represented by the blue line.
comments.author: Balmung83

comments.text:
My solution to this is to use Peat Pots
they are made for transplanting seed germinations. Once transplanted, the peat pot becomes part of the earth and the roots can grow past the peat pot.
http://gardenclub.homedepot.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/peat-pots-SS_233352328.jpg
comments.author: Balmung83

comments.text: Hi Balmung83, I see what you mean. While this was designed initially as a nursery for small plants before moving them to another place when bigger, it can be an issue if you keep them in this for a long period. I will work on another model or an insert to offer a solution for people who want to keep the plants in the planter.

title: E3D V6 Carriage with Autoleveling and M3 Nut

description.text:
This is a remix of the popular Anet A8 E3D V6 carriage. I added a mount for an 18mm autoleveling sensor. Also i added inserts for m3 nuts to secure the cap even better. This will not wear out over time. The cap now has a tiny gap between it and the carriage. This way it can press against the e3d v6 even stronger which secures it better. There is no movement anymore.

Offsets: (Anet A8)
#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 30 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 8 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]

#define X_MIN_POS -10

// Set the boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach).
#define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20
#define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 190
#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20
#define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 190

With these boundaries mine hits the x endstop when it probes the left points so it is really close to hitting the plastik on the side. If you are not comfortable with this change the left probe bed position to a higher value.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

0.1

30%

description.text:
Replacement potentiometer knobs for the FrSky Taranis QX7. A bit larger than the stock ones, measuring 13mm at the bottom. Despite of the larger diameter, there is still plenty of clearance between the forefinger and the knob if you are pinching. In my opinion they give much better grip than the small and slippery stock ones.

Replacement is very straight forward, they are just press fitted to the potentiometer shafts. It took a quite a bit force to remove the stock ones, but it should be doable. These fit nice and tight on the shafts with given print settings but due to many variables I can't guarantee the same fit for you. If they print too tight or loose, just scale them in slicer by 1% at a time. They should be a pretty tight fit, however.

I used a sharpie to color the center triangle and then sanded it with 800 grit wet sanding paper to give a smooth finish.

Printer:

Tronxy

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

0.12mm layer height
3 perimeters
15mm/s perimeter speed
20mm/s infill
10mm/s bridging speed

print_settings.Notes:: Wall, top and bottom thickness of 1.6mm to allow for sanding to remove print lines.

description.text:
I was looking for a small silent fidget. One without clicky buttons or switches, but I couldn't find exactly what I wanted. So I designed this.
The fidget has an indentation on one side for rubbing with your thumb. It also has a built in bearing so that the fidget can be spun, swung and flicked. It is also a nice size to fit discretely into your hand. It also prints as a single piece.
This is not designed to be a spinner as such and it is unweighted and unbalanced.
The printed texture feels OK, but I prefer the fidget after it has been sanded smooth.

The second version includes an embedded keyring so that the fidget can be clipped onto a key-ring. To embed the ring set your printer to pause at 6.4mm and drop the ring in. The small block printed along with the fidget will keep the ring flat as the top prints.
It will accommodate a ring with an ID of 20mm and OD of 26mm. I have included the 123d file if you need to tweak the ring size.

There are two versions as some of my filament would not handle the 0.2mm tolerance for the spinner button / bearing. The slack bearing version has a 0.5mm tolerance.

I've only tested this in PLA.

Printer:

Anet A8 (i3 clone)

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print this slowly. The tolerance gap of the bearing is unforgiving at speed. I found the best results were at 30-40mm/s (prints in under an hour)

I also used Cura 2.5 and enabled Print outer walls before inner walls. This helps with accuracy of the tolerance gap.
I also set Z-Seam alignment to random, so that any extrusion problems did not form a solid joint in one location between the main body and the bearing.

Wall, top and bottom thickness of 1.6mm to allow for sanding to remove print lines.

Once the fidget is complete, the bearing may need a little encouragement to spin freely. On both versions this took a firm twist of the bearing, no tools were needed.

Any filament artefacts between the main body and bearing will wear down with use, resulting in a nice feel to the rotation.

The fidget does not require any further attention. I prefer the feeling of smooth plastic, so took a little time to sand the fidget smooth. I used a 180 grit and then a 240 grit sandpaper to get the texture I liked.

Why you should use this:

  • The battery is not over your ear anymore, so it's way more comfortable
  • It works as a counterweight for the goggles.

Instructions:

  • Print it in a flexible filament
  • Get an extension cable for your battery

title: Understeer handlebar extension for recumbent bike
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Cet ensemble de pièces constitue une extension de guidon-dessous pour vélo couché. Il est destiné à accueillir une commande 5 boutons de kit assistance électrique, normalement installé sur guidon horizontal. Il permet aussi d’ajouter une sonnette. Aisément adaptable en longueur ou diamètre du tube de guidon.
Pour le filetage, j’utilise la librairie http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8793. Il faudrait réduire la taille du filetage sur le bouchon car ça coince un peu.

This set of pieces is an extension to the understeer handlebar of a recumbent bike. It is intended to secure a 5 buttons command set for an e-bike kit designed for an horizontal handlebar. It can also accommodate a bell. Easy to adapt for different lengths or tube diameter.
For the threading, internal and on lid, I’m making use of this library: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8793 but the lid thread should be a bit decreased as it’s a little hard to screw in.

comments.text: I have a few tips in order to improve the design. I already love it though! My tip would be instead of having the the large cylinders screw into each other, have each end be a hole with threads, and a shaft with threads that fits inside it. This would mean that if one of the segments of the stand breaks, you can just print a small segment instead of printing a whole new shaft. Also a larger foot design would benefit larger headphones. Other than that, a great model!

comments.text: I really enjoy your stand design for smaller prints, I have a Materia 101 myself, and it worked really well. The only thing that I would like to see as alternatives is longer feet to better accommodate heavier earphones, pegs instead of threads for an easier assembly , had a bit of trouble with the top cap, even with lube, and that the top cap have a flat part somewhere on the side to get some leverage. With the posts you can easily get enough leverage to properly screw them in but the cap on top is to small, at least for me, to do the same. Thanks for the awesome small print design.

description.text:
I made some wheels for the 3D Lab Print Spitfire landing gear from donandtheresa.
You can find the complete landing gear here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2308436

I remixed some rim+tire that i downloaded from thingiverse anytime in the past but i have not saved the info file and can't find the original. If someone finds, please contact me with the link so I can mark it as a remix!

The tire is scaled to fit the 50mm landing gear Wheel. Print the rim with PLA or ABS and the tire with Flex Filament.

the printed rim with 3 top and bottim layers and 2 walls and 15% infill weights about 3 grams. Ture is not yet printed because I can't print flexible Filament on my A8 because of bowden print and a friend of me will do that for me. I will update with Pictures and if it works but if someone will try, I'd be happy to get some Pictures and results.

I modified the rims to make better air flow.

Print with 2 walls and with longer shaft facing down. Add support with high density to get good round edges on first layer and 0.3mm space to model, and add raft.

I made a version for 3mm rods but need to be drilled out a bit depending on your printer settings to have a good connection without whobbeling. I also added a 3.5mm version thet should fit on an 3mm rod whithout drilling.

I've never been happy with the tight separation between the belt mounts and the belt. The hex screws rub the belt and visibly wear it down near the pully. So, I sat down and created a version with the hex screws positioned 2mm further away from the belt.

update: I noticed my replacement rubbed the metal frame near the Y idler mount, so I had to trim of 1,5mm from the top to make it as high as the original, but only have the screw and insert hole displaced. Hope this is still strong enough.

I decided to keep the old one here as well, it can safely be used on the X-axis, so is a better replacement there. So, print both X and Y axis beltmount replacements and take care of using the right one in the rigth place.

update 2: I edited the Y-axis version to be asymmetric to keep maximum strength on the side that didn't rub the frame.

Robot kit for breadboard – Version 2

Il s'agit seulement d'une mise à jour ou complément du projet initial :
Kit pour transformer une breadbord en voiture Arduino – Version 1
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2249831

Ici le patin de glissement et le centre de gravité sont rapprochés des roues pour faciliter la rotation.
Le pièces « sup_Pil9V_Patin_x + AvecSup_patin-x» de la version 2 remplacent les pièces « AvecSupport1 + patin-socle et sup_Pil_9V_b» de la version 1
Ajout d'un support pour interrupteur de diamètre 10 mm

Ce kit est en essai sur un projet de SEB03000 que je remercie, je vous invite à voir son projet qui est très bien expliqué :

http://robotique-projet.lebonforum.com/t384-comment-faire-votre-premier-robot-en-utilisant-une-arduino

( pour régler le programme au kit il est nécessaire de diminuer les temporisations de rotation)

sup_Pil9V_Patin_x : SUPORT NO
AvecSup_patin-x : SUPPORT YES
/* ****
Hey! This thing is still a Work in Progress. Files, instructions, and other stuff might change!
**** */

Arduino Arduino Car Kit - Version 2

It is only an update or completion of the initial project:
Kit to transform a breadbord into a car Arduino - Version 1
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2249831

Here the sliding pad and the center of gravity are brought close to the wheels to facilitate rotation.
The parts "sup_Pil9V_Patin_x + WithSup_patin-x" of version 2 replace the parts "WithSupport1 + skid-base and sup_Pil_9V_b" of version 1

comments.text: Horizontal expansion can greatly help you if the tolerance of the print is important. Due to the slight deformation of plastics the actual dimensions of the print may not completely correspond with the dimensions of the digital model. By adjusting the horizontal expansion value you can compensate for this slight deviation. A higher value will increase the X/Y size of the model, while a negative value decreases the X/Y size.

comments.text:
I must say that these are lovely! I admire the patience it must have taken to put in so much detail in solidworks. As a slight issue, whenever I print the gun barrels the bottom surface always seems to be omitted, resulting in an inverted u-shaped cross section. Any idea why this might be?
Thanks again for these models!
comments.author: Prussian1740

comments.text: It is a deliberate design decision for the 1:200 models. It gives a bigger flat surface for the gun barrel to print onto, which: 1) prevents the gun barrel becoming detached and curling up & 2) having half of the barrel get not printed at 0.2mm resolutions due to the width being less than the printer can print. At 1:200 it isn't very visible. At 1:100, use the redrawn ones where possible.
comments.author: Prussian1740

comments.text: Ok.  Just to be clear (since i don't think I worded things well), I meant a hollow "U", not just a flat bottom.  As in only the outside edges of the barrel bottom are printing, leaving the barrels hollow and open when looking from the bottom side.  it doesn't happen when I orient the barrels vertically, however.  Maybe its just the slicer I'm using (I've been using Cura).  I'll have to experiment more.
comments.author: m_bergman

comments.text: I think it is your slicer since mine print without any issues and aren't hollow
comments.author: Prussian1740

comments.text: Might I ask which slicer you use?  I've been playing around with different ones trying to find what works.
comments.author: hendrikdc

comments.text: I'm using the velleman slicer (don't recall its true name but i believe you can download it for free from the velleman website)
comments.author: Prussian1740

comments.text: In case anyone else is having the same problem, here's what I did: I reduced extrusion width from 0.4mm to 0.35mm, which allowed the slicing software to fit in an extra extrusion to fill in the barrels.  Worked like a charm!

comments.text: In 1:200 I always print the vehicles sitting on their tracks/wheels, and turrets with the gun barrels horizontal, for maximun strength (that's why the gun barrels have flat undersides). People printing these at FOW scales tend to prefer them sitting on their tails. Either way, never assume that the default orientation of an STL must be the correct one - use your experience to decide that. In this case, Solidworks offers up this orientation as default, and with hundreds of vehicles it's too much bother for me to adjust, especially as most people prefer the default anyway.

comments.author: Voradams

comments.text:
The parts are designed with 0.2mm as a layer height, so should be fine for the Mini.
All gun barrels should be printed horizontal on the UP, for strength and best finish. At 15mm scale, removing the supports should not be too great an issue, since I can manage it at 1:200. I use 0mm^2 and 80 degrees, and don't have too much trouble. Just nibble away at and pull out all the zig-zag support stuff first, then peel away the face mat. For prying out the underhanging bits, use an old xacto blade with the cutting edge and tip filed down to round. That'll give you a very strong poke-prod tool with a 0.5mm thick blade, but one that is too blunt to stab yourself with. Also suggest you try rotating the models 45 degrees in XY plane, because on the UP this gives much better side finish.
No Rattes for you. It wouldn't even fit on the table... Now a Karl, on the other hand...

description.text:
I downloaded the primary model from MakerBeck and worked from there. The original print was going to take 7 hours and a good amount of material, so I wanted to try and make a more minimal design. I split the stand into two smaller pieces and added a support piece to hold them together. I got the print time to around 3 hours using 10% infill and am quite happy with this stand.
hobiej.blogspot.com

I combined the two supports into one print operation, which I did without a raft. The pin was printed with a raft and support to try and create the best cylinder profile as possible. I had a problem with the ends of the pin warping and looking more like a filleted triangle, but a little love from a file made it fit real nice. Thanks to MakerBeck for the original design, happy printing!

title: Solidoodle Torsional Anti-Backlash Nut for Z-Axis

description.text: Specifically designed for the Solidoodle 2 with the aluminum platform and original lead-screw. It can be used with or without the nut attached to the platform. This design has not been tested yet. It will definitely help with backlash from changing direction in Z, but I don't know how much it will help with wobble or Z banding caused by an eccentric lead screw. In order to make it work you will need to make a spring of the correct size. This design was inspired from a Kerk anti-backlash nut I saw the other day. I was trying to replicate the idea, but had to redesign it because of constraints on the size. So this is the best I could do. Not sure how useful the customizable version will be at this point, but here's the link: http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=232253

rev 2.0 - I removed the printed threads because I decided they are redundant and cause too much friction. Instead, the spring will act on the upper nut counterclockwise, "clamping" the two nuts together.  
rev 2.1 - I removed an unnecessary feature which allowed me to reduce the diameter a bit. This should make it a little bit easier to install.

• spring
  • two 5/16-18 nuts (or one if you have the original threaded insert)
  • small sheet of rubber gasket material (not critical, but it will help ensure consistent pressure between the two nuts)

1) Print out the parts with 2 perimeters and 25% infill (not critical)
2) Create a torsion spring out of some wire, bending up both ends. I made one using wire from a large spiral binder notebook and it seems to give enough torsion.
3) Cut your gasket material into a ring shape that will fit in between the Base and the Top
4) Assemble

description.header: How to Install the Anti-Backlash Nut:
description.text:
• Piece together the anti-backlash assembly, including lead screw nuts, but do not put torsion on the spring yet.
    • If you have the original threaded insert on the platform, make sure to only insert a nut in the Top and not in the Base.
    • If you have it, insert the rubber gasket ring in between the Top and the Base. This will make for more consistent pressure between the two nuts.
  • Put onto the lead screw by turning the lead screw while holding the assembly together.
  • Screw the anti-backlash assembly onto the platform.
  • Add torsion to the spring, tightening the upper lead screw nut.

description.text: Soporte sencillo para iwatch

title: Cheapo substitutes for lm8uu bearing and linear rod for tinkering

description.text:
I am always looking for cheap experimenter parts, and one of the big expenses when tinkering with 3d printing is the linear rods and bearings. I use a 3d-printed PLA ‘sleeve bushing’ and cheap hardware store 5/16” carbon steel rod with heavy silicone spray. It works really well for experimenting as a stand-in for proper bearings and rod while prototyping or whatever, though I have not tried it for long-term use (not sire it would work that well since it the friction would likely heat up the PLA and deform it). Since decent bearings are a few bucks a piece, and proper long 8mm rod is like $10-20 depending on length, this can save $big bucks$ on prototyping and experimenting if you are trying out a build with like… 8 linear rods and a dozen bearings.

This bushing model is about the same OUTTER dimensions as an LM8uu, so depending on printing tolerance, they fit in bearing retainers or anywhere you will eventually be placing a bearing, while sliding nicely on the cheapo hardware store rod. To get the inner dimensions tight, I heat up a scrap of 8mm rod and with a bench torch (since it is slightly larger than the 5/16” rod we will be using), press the bushing onto it, and let it cool a bit. Then I tap the rod piece out with a rubber mallet and let the bushing cool completely. Once the bushing is cool, it will shrink down slightly and fit very nicely on the 5/16” rod.

5/16” rod is nearly 8mm: the difference in nominal diameter is 0.3125” for 5/16 vs 0.31496” for 8mm, which is so close that it is actually within tolerance spec for regular lower-grade 8mm rod, so lm8uu will actually run on it (but don't do it for long since but they will bit both a bit loose and they will bite into the metal since the rod is not chromed: they are usually cold-rolled 1027/1527 plain carbon steel). Hardware store rod usually has some kind of coating on it, so I scrub it down with steel wool or a scotch-brite pad, then polish it up as best you can and wipe it down with rubbing alcohol or whatever.

After that, spray down the 5/16” rod with silicone and run the bearing up and down it for a while, then wipe off the excess spray. If you did it right, the bushing will have about the same (or less) play as a linear ball bearing, but should move freely enough that you can flick it with your finger, and it will fly down the rail smoothly. (See Video at https://youtu.be/YkAGpYWHmFU )

PLA has a friction coefficient of slightly under 0.5, which is about in the upper range for nylon — and about twice that of something like an Igus bearing — but silicone spray cuts that almost in half. It also has the side benefit of keeping the steel rod from rusting until you get your proper rods in.

I have not tried these on cheap unhardened unchromed 8mm metric rod, but you would need a slightly larger diameter rod to heat up and form the inner surface… so maybe a scrap of 9mm rod?

Alejandra Gonzalez, Faith Skinner
The Magicians Monopoly Rules

One player becomes the Banker, who distributes assets from the Bank to the players. Only the player in question can use their money, money can only be lent via the Banker. Each player receives two $500, four $100, one $50, one $20, two $10, one $5, and five $1. Each player begins the game with $1500.
On a player's turn, he or she must roll the dice and move his or her token forward the number of spaces as rolled on the dice.If the player lands on an unowned property, he or she may buy it for the price listed on that property's space. If he or she agrees to buy it, he or she pays the Bank the amount shown on the property space and receives the deed for that property.If the player lands on an mortgaged property owned by another player, he or she pays rent to that person, as specified on the property's deed. It is the property owner's responsibility to demand rent, and he or she has until the beginning of the second following player's turn to do so.If the player lands on his or her own property, or on property which is owned by another player but currently mortgaged, nothing happens.
If the player lands on Luxury Tax/Super Tax, he or she must pay the Bank $100.If the player lands on Income Tax he or she must pay the Bank either $200.
If the player lands on the Dungeon space, he or she is "Just Visiting". No penalty applies.If the player lands on the Go to the dungeon square, he or she must move his token directly to the dungeon.
Players may not loan money to other players. Only the Bank can loan money.If a player skips another player's turn and is caught, the turn is transferred back to the player whose turn was skipped.
The only way to win is if the player remains the only player with the money

title: Parts Storage Rack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It's time to get organized with these parts storage racks and compartment cases that you can pick up from your local Daiso Japan discount store. Use the cases for storing screws, electrical components, or any other small parts, and keep your cases in these convenient and space-efficient racks. This Thing includes versions of the rack able to hold 4, 5, or 6 compartment cases. The racks are designed to be compatible with all slotted Wall Control metal pegboards that are 8 inches or more in height. An additional compartment case can also be on the top of the rack. Two or more racks can be installed vertically, leaving just enough space for a case to fit snuggly between racks.

Wall Control metal pegboards are strong, durable, and look great - making them a common addition to garages and workshops everywhere. This storage rack is compatible with all slotted Wall Control pegboards 8 inches or more in height. Racks are designed to allow the placement of an additional compartment case on the top. Two racks installed vertically leaves just enough space for a case to fit snuggly between racks.

The Daiso compartment cases are hinged with two front latches for secure closure. Each case contains 11 compartments. Some of a case's dividers can be removed to create fewer but larger compartments able to hold larger parts or more of the same type of part.

I've listed this Thing on eBay for those who find it to be too big for their printer.

If you have Wall Control pegboards in your shop then you should also check out these shelf units here on Thingiverse, and this mounting system for your Chargepoint EV Charger on eBay.

Come on, get your life together!

Printer:

gMax 1.5+ XT

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Installing on pegboard

This Thing is compatible with all Wall Control metal pegboards with slots and 8 inches in height or taller. Two short Wall Control brackets are needed to install the rack onto the pegboard.

Begin by slipping the top portion of each bracket into the top two slits on the back of the rack. The brackets need to rotate counter-clockwise as the turned up portion finds its way into the slit of the rack. The bottom of the bracket might need a little bit extra convincing, which you can give them by pushing them against a hard surface. Just be careful that the bracket is following the internal path. See the photo of this Thing for comparison.

Now that you've fitted the brackets into the rack, remove the brackets and install them into to properly spaced slots of the pegboard. With the rack at a 45-degree angle relative to the pegboard, allow the turned-up part of both brackets to find the same top-most opening that you'd previously slipped them into. Making sure that the top back of the rack remains against the pegboard, rotate the rack down until both the top and bottom of the rack's back are flush against the pegboard.

And you're done.

The body should be printed with support, the bumpers and shocks don't necessarily need it but I printed them with support as well.

title: ImpulseRC Helix ZX6 Extra Durable Fairing

description.text:
These are ZX6 fairings that are just shy of 2mm thick! They accomodate an ESC up to 40mm by 20mm.

There is a per-request version which is taller, has more room for motor wires at the tip, as well as a larger pass-through for wiring to the PDB. It is sized to fit the T-motor F45a ESCs.

There is also a version custom sized for the T-motor F30a ESCs.

Started from a blank model, and a trace of the Helix arms, et voila! A durable Helix fairing with tons of room for ESCs. I'll update this more later, but max ESC height is 20mm!! Length is 40mm. Thickness is roughly 1.8mm all around, so in PETG this means you're just about indestructible!

Prints awesome with 0.2mm layer height, 100% infill. It needs support, but I've been pleasantly surprised with how little it actually needs.

I plan to make a couple of versions of this, so stay tuned! Currently in the works are a lightweight version, ventilated version, LED integrated version, screwless self-locating ziptie version, motor guard, and minimalist version. And I guess various permutations of those.

Please comment if you have any suggestions/specific needs or sizes. Happy to accommodate.

I spent a ton of time modeling and developing, testing, et cetera to make it absolutely perfect. If it works well for you, a tip of any amount would be appreciated. That'll help the developments and other great stuff coming! Even 25 cents helps! Plus, it'll get your request noticed ;)

The ZX5 Fairings are here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2296697

If you can adjust the design or post a source file that I can adjust?  Happy to make a donation if you can create a new version :)

Guaranty Building
Buffalo, NY

Structure designed by Louis Sullivan and Dankmar Adler. Built in 1896 by Guaranty Construction Company. Originally commissioned by Hascal Taylor. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1975

Note: This is an extremely rough draft/my working copy at the moment. The model needs to be scaled down to a more manageable print size, and I haven't yet figured out the best print settings. I intend to add more detail at a later time. This is my first CAD project, so I am well aware that it is far from perfect.

title: SB-900 and SB-910 SPOT GRID and GEL Adapter V2.0

description.text:
Adapter to fit Nikon SB-900 and SB-910 speedlights. Collimates the light into a narrow beam and allows you to add a gel. There are 2 circular holes on the sides of the bracket, grid and gel only adapters to glue in 10mm diameter x 3mm Magnets (Jaycar.com.au part # LM-1622). One of the multicolour images shows the magnets (in red) fitted.

Standard Rosco sample pack size will work perfectly.

There are also 2 tabs that allows fixing to the flash with a rubber band if the little clips inside wear out. They also will help in removing it from the flash as pulling handles.

GEL CLAMP (7 June 2017) added. I printed it out (again at a low res 0.2 and only 20% infill) and it looks OK. The idea is to clamp a gel between this (or the grid adapter) and the bracket. Soon I'll publish a slightly wider grid, keep watching.

NB!! If you wish to shoot rapidly and/or full power, please ensure the vent holes in the bracket are nice and open. Speedlights generate a fair chunk of heat and you risk melting the gel or speelight fresnel lens.

UPDATE (6 June 2017): Added in the updated grid and slightly altered the magnet holder on the bracket. Removed the gel only, will post when I have printed and confirmed fit. Also added some images of the printed versions and results on using (the mask is called Donald Dump LOL - I often use him to test lighting setups. 1st picture is flash only, second is with grid fitted). Note that I printed the grid on 0.2 low resolution and only 20% infill. I looks OK and is strong enough. If you want, change to 0.1 layer height. Let me know how it turns out for you. There is a fair bit of cleanup with support material so choose wisely..... I used white silicone to glue in the magnets (you'll need 4).

Prior to 6 June 2017:
This is the updated version. It should fit better. All older versions removed.
UPDATE - I have printed the BRACKET. Disclaimer: I have printed only the bracket so far and the magnet holes are a bit tight. Other than the magnet holes I am quite pleased, it sits nice and snugly on my SB-900 and clips into the little slots on the side. Fitting for the grid and gel only options are unconfirmed as I have not printed them yet. Print at your own risk.

I have also added vent holes and moved the grid/gel a few mm away from the speedlight fresnel lens as, when a flash is fired in rapid succession, there can be quite a lot of generated heat.

Printer:

Anet A8 (Prusa i3 clone)

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

I have not printed this yet so it is unproven. There may be a bit of an issue clearing out the supports in the gel slot.

remixed_from.author: prefect42
remixed_from.title: Amazon Echo Dot Gen 2 Wall Mount

description.text:
Thanks for all the hard work done by TinkeringT, prefect42, and cptskippy before me. I loved each of the designs and put them all together for a simpler print. The design allows for use of the second outlet as well as this mount at the same time. You can use either the top or the bottom outlet as the ring supporting the dot is encompassing. The plug is a snug fit as cptskippy says, I found that running a knife or scraper around the front edge allows for a smooth install. This thing works perfectly for my needs, hopefully you will enjoy to also. I now have a nice way to keep the dot off the kitchen counter and living room end tables.

Update - I have added a UK option for the USB plug. If you have larger usb plug this may work for you as well. There are a few options that should provide a working solution. If you need something else adjusted please comment and I will attempt it.

I plan to use this Micro USB Cable - Rerii Golden Plated 15cm Length Micro-B Male Right Angle USB cable, Sync & Charging Micro USB Cable to have a nice clean cable for install.

if you want to reduce file sizes, use Meshlab, really awesome program..
Then load model, and goto the Filter menu.
Next choose (remeshing, simplification, reconstruction)
Then select (Quadric Edge Collapse Decimation)
you can choose the number of vertices or faces and see the output file size.
Does a pretty good job.

author: fireshaper

description.text: So I discovered that having desiccant by itself in a closed box really didn't remove the moisture very well because there was no air circulation so I created this to force the air to the dessicant. I have mine connected to a small wall wart and find that plugging it in for a couple hours drops the humidity to about 25%. Once the moisture is removed, it can be unplugged and if you have a good box should stay indefinitely. I have the fan blowing down into the desiccant. I've noticed that the first 2 inches of the jar with the fan is starting to turn green while the other jar with no lid is all still completely orange. This is a remix of 2 different designs. I left the customizer enabled and it should work but certain combinations don't make sense.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8eJr0fn0B4x

An alternative to the hard to get - Google AIY kit. This is basically a speaker box with space for a pi zero (and a bit more).

The speaker is a common 3 inch 4 ohm which is delivered with the Google AIY kit, and readily available from other sources (eg. Adafruit).

See it in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eeX9NlU-ESQ. I'm using the Zenbu-Hat which will be available at nyumaya.com for amp and mic. But using breakout boards (max98357a for amp and SPH0645LM4H for mic) should work too but this can be a bit fiddly.

The new version features a nicer speaker grill and enough space for the raspberry camera
cable.

The ugly gap from the previous version is now gone.
For contributions drop me a pull request at github: https://github.com/yodakohl/PiZeroSpeaker

My kids love their Bounty Hunter Junior Metal Detector. We needed a better way to store it instead of on the garage floor where it can easily get damaged. description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kQdgR7KWu84

for a setup using the Discov3ry paste extruder
my printer needed a holder that can allow me to use a remote syringe tip. here it is.

I uploaded an STL file with the whole setup all lined up. when its assembled, It lines up the
nozzle tip in the same position as the stock FDM extruder nozzle.

find the 3mm rods from on old cd-rom drive or floppy drive and stick them in these holes. you really need to press them in, so use the rods themselves and a drill to press through the rods in, OR play with the hole size in your CAD program. You need to able to slide the tip up/down in a pinch or to adjust it to the right height without re-slicing.

the less you mess with the holes the tighter your sliding action will be so the tip holder can maintain your height. but make sure you consider compromising because you could see the printer about to make a bad move and want to lift the tip out of the way.

for the tip holder you must consider using your design program to tweak the holder to match your specific equipment- such as the tubing to luer lock female fitting.

print the tip holder and assemble it on your printer and you likely need to tweak parts so i include the disign files .stp .sap and 123dx.

description.text: To assemble, download and print the axel above. If you have your broken axel still partially attached to the car, disassemble and remove the broken axel. Remove the screws and suspension. Next, insert the new axel into the groove and slid the pin through. Repeat the same process for the wheel. Now, screw in the shock absorber to the axel (note: take small knife and shave a slight amount of the rim of the hole to widen). Finally, screw the remaining pieces back onto the car. If you have any trouble, look at the other axel.

title: Extrusion Corner Plate Brackets for 1515, 2020, 2525, 3030, or 4040
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Extrusion corner brackets with built-in plates. Short and tall versions for 2020, 3030, and 4040 extruded aluminum -- and now with 2525. Print three of each for each corner.

I like to break things down to essential patterns and make things printable without support. Also, I try to incorporate orientation for making the strongest parts.

By printing them in three parts, it should reduce the print time about 10-15% or much more since you can print without supports. Printing them flat this way should also give greater strength in all directions since the part is rotated for each corner direction.

1515 has M3 holes and 5mm thick.
2020 and 2525 have M5 holes and 5mm thick.
3030 and 4040 have M8 holes and are 6mm thick (new version of 3030 short has M6 holes).

Updated: 1515 added with M3 holes, 3030 short added with M6 holes, 2020 short added wth notch for pass-thru extrusion, 3030 short added wth notch for pass-through extrusion. Remember, tipping is great encouragement!

This is currently experimental and open to suggestions.

If you this helps and want to encourage my insanity, buy a cup of coffee for me, a bag of coffee, or you pick the value. Thanks!

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2-0.24 mm

Infill:

25-60% -- 3 or more outlines

Notes:

Print in groups of 3 for each corner. They should print flat and then join all together. It is designed with a 0.2mm offset that works well for most of my printers.

The more outlines/perimeters and denser the infill, the stronger they should be.

title: Anet A6 X-Axis with Anti wobble and tensioner. Now compatible with Manual bed levelling

description.text:
Anet A6 X-Axis belt tensioner with Z-Axis Anti wobble. This Anet A6 X-Axis belt tensioner does not put any strain on the Z rod, as there is 2 adjustable M4 screws that push against the X-guide rail. Make sure a m4 nut is place inside the right axis lock so the pressure is not exerted on the z rods. X-axis should be freely move up and down without any binding after installed

Just added an optional Z-Axis End Stop Limit Switch Bracket for those who has not set up Auto Bed Level, and still use Manual Bed Levelling

Added an optional 6mm z-motor spacer that can be installed to lower your z-motor in order to give you that extra 6mm clearance between the anti wobble holder and the z motor coupler.

Requires 5 pieces 33~40mm m4 screw and m4 nut 7 pieces.
same spring used by heat bed for z-height adjustment (Optional).

5 pieces 40mm m3 screws for z guided rod bearing and tensioner.
8 pieces 12~14mm m3 screws for trapezoidal guide nut.
1 piece 26mm m3 screw for clamping right x-axis
3 pieces 18mm m3 screws for z limit switch bracket
m3 nuts 15 pieces and a m3 tensioner thumb nut

stepper motor screws can obtain from your existing x-axis motor

Revised Left and Right X-Axis mount for greater flexibility to allow for;-

  1. Configuration for Suspended Anti-wobble (existing setup).
  2. Anet A6 original Z fixed threaded nut configuration
  3. added x endstop switch holes for more customization for various x-carriage

There is suppose to be 2 m4 nuts placed inside of these particular lock.  The 8mm rods should enter about 6~8mm in and NOT all the way through, as there are 2 m4 screws, one for each rod that allows you to adjust the x-axis tension against the z-rod to prevent any bend on your z-axis.  Just make sure the 8mm rod went all the way thru the left and right carriage,  The left rod should be stop at right at the motor mount.

title: Winco Brand Children's Acetaminophen(Tylenol) Syringe Adapter

description.text: I've got two toddler boys at home. There are a lot of bumps, bruises and fevers around here. Somewhere along this ride we noticed that the concentration of the Winco Brand Infants Pain Relief solution and the Winco Brand Children's Pain Relief solution are the same. The infant version is twice the cost with half the volume. The infant bottle has a rubber adapter and accepts a little dosage syringe which it comes with. The Children's version lacks the syringe but they are totally reusable. Print this part so that you can use the syringe with the Children's size bottle. This will cut the cost by a factor of 4 for parents of infants.

author: Cpalangio

description.text:
This design is part of the ongoing work of the E-Nable group.
For more information on where to connect with people who can help someone in need with sizing, printing and/or assembly a mechanical hand please join the e-NABLE Google+ Community entitled, e-NABLE:
https://plus.google.com/communities/102497715636887179986
For more information and stories:
http://enablingthefuture.org
https://www.facebook.com/enableorganization This thing is intended as a "digital building block" that can be added to other designs. Please note that the photo of a 3D print involving this design is an example of the tensioner after it was incorporated into another device. The STL file for the tensioner block can be imported into design software and then added to the structure of other objects. This device allows the tension on a cable to be adjusted by either tightening or loosening a machine screw. The hexagonal pins fit into the hexagonal slots. Then, a machine screw is fit through the hole in the back of the block and threaded into the pin. At the standard size, this design requires machine screws with a diameter of 2mm. Thank you to David and Frankie for providing inspiration for this.

description.text:
Fitted with springs, solder, wires, connectors and hot glue you can charge 18650 batteries with your 1s charger. Solder wires to springs that fit holes, load into place, run wires through smaller holes and hotglue springs in place. I used old rafts to cover hot glue/spring pockets (one red, one black to indicate polarity).

I wanted to make a charger that worked with existing molex 1s connection for a friend. With a hitec x4 micro multi charger (tiny whoop charger) we can charge 4 of these bad boys! Takes a long time but works great.

If you have 15 bucks you are probably better off getting a real charger, but this project was fun and worked.

title: Case for T3 M328 Digital Combo Tester

description.text:
Three piece tester case also holds standard 9V battery.
Meter1.stl replaced 10/20/2017 with Meter1a.stl to correct tiny error in lever slot.

Also needed: seven 3mm x 9mm screws.
Build from face up. Lay board on face section, then place middle section on back of board, simultaneously pulling battery cable through middle section. Add three screws to sandwich the board in place. Note that cut-outs are to clear the components on the back of the board. The 9V battery is stored in the smaller room, connected to the cable. Use four screws to hold the back in place, noting that the back is not x-y symmetrical.

I made this part so I could move the extruder and shorten the bowden tube. The part prints flat with no supports. I did have to place it on the bed at an angle as it was right at the edge of travel with the skirt.

The part is designed to slide over the X-axis extrusion and mount in place with the outer most 2 screws for the X-axis stepper. I did have to use 6mm screws to mount the extruder motor, leave those screws loose until the rest of the stock extruder parts are mounted onto the bracket. Then push the motor tight to the extruder assembly and tighten it in place. For some reason the stock 38.5mm center distance did not work for me so the part has slots. For the bowden tube I would start with a 500mm length and cut it to fit. Last thing I did was to zip tie all of the wires to the bowden tube and then make a cable clamp(strip cut out of a pop bottle) that I mounted to the extruder pivot screw. Almost forgot, The screw for the small extruder gear needs to be replaced with a 3mm set screw to clear the printed bracket

6/11/17
Update: I added another bracket made to support a belt drive. The belt drive setup requires GT2 pulleys with a 60 tooth and 16 tooth count with 5mm bores. For the belt I am using a 79 tooth GT2 x 6mm belt(sourced through sdp-si.com), though I think an 80 tooth would work as well. As a starting point set the steps per mm for E to 538.2.

description.text:
It's a clamp with mounting tabs to secure a Nema17 geared stepper motor to a flat surface.  
In my case it will be used to fix the Kossel mini extruder to the Aluminium frame. The clamp is 15mm thick. The Bore is 36mm diameter.

Use an M3 Nut and bolt to tighten the clamp onto the stepper motor gear housing.  
Use M3 screws to secure the clamp to whatever surface you are working with.

comments.text: Do you appear to have SCAD file for this? I have tried several tools to modify this STL, but with my limited understanding how to play with 3D models haven't been able to change this.

description.text:
I got tired of the stock Colido 3D DIY spool holder, so I created this one. I know it's ugly, but version 1 was even uglier, believe it or not. It works better than I had hoped for and has made filament changes a breeze! Plus the feed mechanics are much improved over the stock spool holder.

I used the stock Z axis screws, I suppose you could use longer screws if you felt it necessary, but I don't believe it is. The spooler base is 5mm thick, but I have recessed the holder screws by 2.5mm, so only 2.5mm of the screws are used.

I printed this using Cura at .2mm and 20% fill. It took around 4 hours to print. Rotate the object so the base is on the print bed (I had to rotate it 180 on X for some reason) It's large, and I needed to rotate the object 45 degrees on the Z.

I used 5/16-18 screw rods with 608 bearings. Choose your favorite 608 pully (The red part) from Thingiverse. I used one that I WISH I could remember who it was from. If I remember then i will credit the individual as soon as I can. (I know the file is just called "poulie.stl" and is 84.6KB, if that helps)

I used 6 bearings to accommodate the two different spool widths that I currently have. You can use only 4 if you want and adjust the spacing for each spool size if necessary.

I used 5/16-18 nuts, by gitrdun (http://www.thingiverse.com/gitrdun/about) for holding the bearings in place http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:71968

The dragon head was modeled in Sculptris and the shield was modeled in inventor. Both were imported and combined in Meshmixer to create a unified watertight mesh. This model was made as a demo for an upcoming class at Danger!Awesome in Cambridge MA. If interested in learning some basics in digital sculpting for 3d printing join our class below: http://www.eventbrite.com/e/digital-sculpting-for-3d-printing-january-2014-tickets-9820211517?aff=eorg

Used standard setting in Maker Ware with raft and support
Changed infill to Linear
Printed on single extruder Makerbot Replicator and changed the filament between the shield and dragon head
